title: 110_hr5906
content: The Act titled "Small Business Capitol Expansion and Improvement Act of 2008" allows for expensing certain real property under section 179F. Under the "Small Business Capitol Expansion and Improvement Act of 2008," taxpayers can elect to treat the cost of qualified real property as an expense not chargeable to capital account, with a limit of $125,000 for the deduction in the year the property is placed in service. This amount is subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2009. Under the "Small Business Capitol Expansion and Improvement Act of 2008," taxpayers can elect to treat the cost of qualified real property as an expense not chargeable to capital account. The cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins is determined by substituting 'calendar year 2008' for 'calendar year 1992'. Any adjusted amount not a multiple of $1,000 shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000. The election for this deduction should be specified on the taxpayer's return of the tax imposed for the taxable year. Under the "Small Business Capitol Expansion and Improvement Act of 2008," taxpayers can elect to treat the cost of qualified real property as an expense not chargeable to capital account. The election, once made, is irrevocable without the Secretary's consent. Qualified real property refers to section 1250 property in the United States with the original use commencing with the taxpayer and placed in service after the enactment of the section. Taxpayers meeting the $5,000,000 gross receipts test in the prior taxable year are described in this subsection. The $5,000,000 gross receipts test determines if a taxpayer meets the criteria based on their average annual gross receipts over a 3-year period. Aggregation rules apply for entities treated as a single employer. If the taxpayer was not in existence for the entire 3-year period, special considerations apply. The $5,000,000 gross receipts test determines eligibility based on average annual gross receipts over a 3-year period. Special rules apply for taxpayers not in existence for the entire period. Reporting requirements must be met for deductions under subsection (a). Conforming amendments are made to section 263(a)(1). The text introduces a new subparagraph (M) allowing deductions under section 179F. Section 312(k)(3)(B) is amended to include 179F. The table of sections is updated to include 179F after 179E. The amendments made by this section allow for the election to expense certain real property, effective for costs incurred after the enactment of this Act.
